LIFE733
Notes
I have made a couple of minor changes to the module:

- I removed mention of machine learning (ML) - this is no longer going to be covered in this module. MSc Bioinformatics students will get a more detailed introduction to machine learning in a different module. ML was not appropriate content for students on other programmes, as it was too advanced.

- I have changed the team working assignment to a regular individual assignment.

- In response to student feedback, I have changed the assignment weighting, so they are now 10:20:30:40 - assignments increase in difficulty and complexity to solve. Previously 10:10:30:50. The justification for 4 assignments (instead of 2 say), remains as before - we need students to engage early and continously to learn coding. With a fewer number of students, there is a risk of only passive engagement until it is too late. We are going to trial some automated grading software this year, to reduce the burden on staff.

The rationale for the changes is that the module was designed for classes of size < 20, where all students joining were keen to learn coding.

We now have a class of >50, including cohorts of students on M-level programmes with no particular interest in coding (e.g. from MSc Infection Immunity, for whom it is a mandatory module - presumably as a cost saving exercise).

As such, I have had to simplify the module to handle the increased number of students, and also the wide range of abilities and interests of the cohort. The team working assignment, while highly desirable for students motivated to learn coding, does not work well for teams that contain students who do not engage in the material and work consistently week-by-week.

Overview

Overview
The aim of the module is to develop skills in Python coding for use in Life Sciences research, for example to prepare students for future work either in bioinformatics or for those planning to work in lab-based biosciences with a need to learn more advanced data analysis methods.

The module will be taught using a combination of lectures and workshops. Lecture material will provide some of the background theory, but interactive workshops will provide the main route for students to gain confidence in their coding skills through both formative and summative assessment.

The module will be assessed via four coursework assessments – two short coding assignments for confidence building, one simple bioinformatics pipeline and one data science mini-project.

Learning materials will be available to students via the University Virtual Learning environment.
Educational Aims
-To provide students with sufficient introductory Python coding knowledge to perform basic tasks within the field of biological sciences.
-To enable students to gain practical experience in writing their own Python scripts for basic bioinformatics tasks, such as, manipulating DNA, RNA and protein sequences, file input/output and working with other programs, such as BLAST.
-To provide students with skills and practical experience in the use of Python for data visualisation and basic statistical analysis (i.e. data science)
Marketing Module Synopsis
This module is aimed at postgraduate students in the Biosciences, wishing to learn about methods for use in data-intensive research. The module provides a broad introduction to the use of Python coding for performing basic tasks in the biological sciences. The student will get practical experience in writing their own Python scripts for basic bioinformatics tasks, such as manipulating DNA, RNA and protein sequences, file input/output and working with other programs, such as BLAST. There is also an introduction to data visualisation using Python, and simple techniques used in data science.

Around 10 hours of lectures will be provided on core topics, with a strong emphasis on practical activity in workshops (totalling around 40 hours), allowing students to gain confidence in writing scripts for their own tasks. The module will be assessed by two short coding assignments, one team working coding assignment building a bioinformatics pipeline, and a data science mini-project.
Outline Syllabus
• Introduction to Python – A basic introduction to the Python3 language (basic datatypes – strings, floats, integers), and the PyCharm software we use for writing code. Basic explanation of errors and how to debug errors.

• List, conditionals and loops – Learning how to use basic structures such as list, Boolean statements (if, elif, else) for changing the flow of code, and for loops for repeated actions.

• Dictionaries, lists and looping structures – Covering the use of a Python Dictionaries, a useful structure for storing and managing data, more detail on using multiple structures and components together.

• Functions – Learning how to structure code into functions with arguments and return values.

• Working with files and regular expressions – experience of reading and writing from text files with Python, and using powerful string manipulations.

• External programmes and BioPython – introduction to calling external command line programmes e.g. BLAST and using the BioPython libraries for sequence-based bioinformatics tasks (BLAST, multiple sequence alignment, phylogenetics).

• Python for data analysis (plotting) – students learn how to process and plot data e.g. using the matplotlib library.

• Python for data science – basic introduction to statistical testing and more advanced data visualisation.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Scheduled Lectures: The lectures will provide the theoretical basis for the practical exercises and the background needed to support the assessments.

Attendance Recorded: yes

Workshops: active-learning workshops, which will focus on real world coding tasks, in order to provide students with hands-on experience. Students will undertake formative exercises in class, with feedback from staff and demonstrators during classes on code written and answers to exercises. Students will be encouraged to work in small groups for formative exercises. Learning is consolidated through formative exercises leading up to Summative assessment, of increasing levels of difficulty, where later assignments rely on earlier knowledge and skills.


Attendance Recorded: yes

The student directed learning element of the module will involve directed reading and accessing online resources. This will require adaptability & organisational skills.

The Liverpool Curriculum Framework is at the centre of this module. Research-connected teaching is embedded in all aspects of teaching. This module contributes to a Programme which is specifically designed to support students for future training in Life Sciences and in collaboration with future potential employers– employability. The teaching approach is designed to give students hand-on experience with bioinformatics and advanced computer skills, promoting Digital Fluency through Active Learning. Student Confidence will be promoted though both skills development and through discussion in class and with their project supervisors.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
Notes (applying to all assessments)
The module will be assessed via four assessments. The assessments are designed with The Liverpool Curriculum Framework in mind and are authentic to the research experience and will give students real life experience of coding and analysing real world big data.

Assessment 1 (10%)– Basic coding assignment in which students demonstrate the use of basic text and numerical handling, as well as conditional statements and looping

Assessment 2 (20%)– Basic coding assignment where students demonstrate the writing of functions and use of file input / output.

Assessment 3 (30%)- Basic pipeline assembly. Students learn to connect up multiple functions, to achieve a simple bioinformatics analysis.

Assessment 4 (40%)– Individual large scripting project to produce an analysis with report 1000 words plus code.

Feedback will be provided to all assessments. Pass mark for all assessments is 50%. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission of all assessments. All assessments are anonymous assessment.

Resit strategy: resit opportunity will be given to the assessment and will have the same format and content as the original assessment, but with substantial revision required and will be submitted during the reassessment window and capped at 50% (pass mark).

Learning materials will be available to students via the University Virtual Learning environment. More details on the assessments are on the table below.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessments may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

The justification for 4 assignments (instead of 2 say), remains as before - we need students to engage early and continously to learn coding. With a fewer number of students, there is a risk of only passive engagement until it is too late. We are going to trial some automated grading software this year, to reduce the burden on staff.

The rationale for the changes is that the module was designed for classes of size < 20, where all students joining were keen to learn coding.

We now have a class of >50, including cohorts of students on M-level programmes with no particular interest in coding (e.g. from MSc Infection Immunity, for whom it is a mandatory module - presumably as a cost saving exercise).

As such, I have had to simplify the module to handle the increased number of students, and also the wide range of abilities and interests of the cohort. The team working assignment, while highly desirable for students motivated to learn coding, does not work well for teams that contain students who do not engage in the material and work consistently week-by-week.

Overview

Overview
The aim of the module is to develop skills in Python coding for use in Life Sciences research, for example to prepare students for future work either in bioinformatics or for those planning to work in lab-based biosciences with a need to learn more advanced data analysis methods.

The module will be taught using a combination of lectures and workshops. Lecture material will provide some of the background theory, but interactive workshops will provide the main route for students to gain confidence in their coding skills through both formative and summative assessment.

The module will be assessed via four coursework assessments – two short coding assignments for confidence building, one simple bioinformatics pipeline and one data science mini-project.

Learning materials will be available to students via the University Virtual Learning environment.
Educational Aims
-To provide students with sufficient introductory Python coding knowledge to perform basic tasks within the field of biological sciences.
-To enable students to gain practical experience in writing their own Python scripts for basic bioinformatics tasks, such as, manipulating DNA, RNA and protein sequences, file input/output and working with other programs, such as BLAST.
-To provide students with skills and practical experience in the use of Python for data visualisation and basic statistical analysis (i.e. data science)
Marketing Module Synopsis
This module is aimed at postgraduate students in the Biosciences, wishing to learn about methods for use in data-intensive research. The module provides a broad introduction to the use of Python coding for performing basic tasks in the biological sciences. The student will get practical experience in writing their own Python scripts for basic bioinformatics tasks, such as manipulating DNA, RNA and protein sequences, file input/output and working with other programs, such as BLAST. There is also an introduction to data visualisation using Python, and simple techniques used in data science.

Around 10 hours of lectures will be provided on core topics, with a strong emphasis on practical activity in workshops (totalling around 40 hours), allowing students to gain confidence in writing scripts for their own tasks. The module will be assessed by two short coding assignments, one team working coding assignment building a bioinformatics pipeline, and a data science mini-project.
Outline Syllabus
• Introduction to Python – A basic introduction to the Python3 language (basic datatypes – strings, floats, integers), and the PyCharm software we use for writing code. Basic explanation of errors and how to debug errors.

• List, conditionals and loops – Learning how to use basic structures such as list, Boolean statements (if, elif, else) for changing the flow of code, and for loops for repeated actions.

• Dictionaries, lists and looping structures – Covering the use of a Python Dictionaries, a useful structure for storing and managing data, more detail on using multiple structures and components together.

• Functions – Learning how to structure code into functions with arguments and return values.

• Working with files and regular expressions – experience of reading and writing from text files with Python, and using powerful string manipulations.

• External programmes and BioPython – introduction to calling external command line programmes e.g. BLAST and using the BioPython libraries for sequence-based bioinformatics tasks (BLAST, multiple sequence alignment, phylogenetics).

• Python for data analysis (plotting) – students learn how to process and plot data e.g. using the matplotlib library.

• Python for data science – basic introduction to statistical testing and more advanced data visualisation.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Scheduled Lectures: The lectures will provide the theoretical basis for the practical exercises and the background needed to support the assessments.

Attendance Recorded: yes

Workshops: active-learning workshops, which will focus on real world coding tasks, in order to provide students with hands-on experience. Students will undertake formative exercises in class, with feedback from staff and demonstrators during classes on code written and answers to exercises. Students will be encouraged to work in small groups for formative exercises. Learning is consolidated through formative exercises leading up to Summative assessment, of increasing levels of difficulty, where later assignments rely on earlier knowledge and skills.


Attendance Recorded: yes

The student directed learning element of the module will involve directed reading and accessing online resources. This will require adaptability & organisational skills.

The Liverpool Curriculum Framework is at the centre of this module. Research-connected teaching is embedded in all aspects of teaching. This module contributes to a Programme which is specifically designed to support students for future training in Life Sciences and in collaboration with future potential employers– employability. The teaching approach is designed to give students hand-on experience with bioinformatics and advanced computer skills, promoting Digital Fluency through Active Learning. Student Confidence will be promoted though both skills development and through discussion in class and with their project supervisors.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
Notes (applying to all assessments)
The module will be assessed via four assessments. The assessments are designed with The Liverpool Curriculum Framework in mind and are authentic to the research experience and will give students real life experience of coding and analysing real world big data.

Assessment 1 (10%)– Basic coding assignment in which students demonstrate the use of basic text and numerical handling, as well as conditional statements and looping

Assessment 2 (20%)– Basic coding assignment where students demonstrate the writing of functions and use of file input / output.

Assessment 3 (30%)- Basic pipeline assembly. Students learn to connect up multiple functions, to achieve a simple bioinformatics analysis.

Assessment 4 (40%)– Individual large scripting project to produce an analysis with report 1000 words plus code.

Feedback will be provided to all assessments. Pass mark for all assessments is 50%. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission of all assessments. All assessments are anonymous assessment.

Resit strategy: resit opportunity will be given to the assessment and will have the same format and content as the original assessment, but with substantial revision required and will be submitted during the reassessment window and capped at 50% (pass mark).

Learning materials will be available to students via the University Virtual Learning environment. More details on the assessments are on the table below.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessments may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

The module will be assessed by two short coding assignments, one team working coding assignment building a bioinformatics pipeline, and a data science mini-project.
Outline Syllabus
• Introduction to Python – A basic introduction to the Python3 language (basic datatypes – strings, floats, integers), and the PyCharm software we use for writing code. Basic explanation of errors and how to debug errors.

• List, conditionals and loops – Learning how to use basic structures such as list, Boolean statements (if, elif, else) for changing the flow of code, and for loops for repeated actions.

• Dictionaries, lists and looping structures – Covering the use of a Python Dictionaries, a useful structure for storing and managing data, more detail on using multiple structures and components together.

• Functions – Learning how to structure code into functions with arguments and return values.

• Working with files and regular expressions – experience of reading and writing from text files with Python, and using powerful string manipulations.

• External programmes and BioPython – introduction to calling external command line programmes e.g. BLAST and using the BioPython libraries for sequence-based bioinformatics tasks (BLAST, multiple sequence alignment, phylogenetics).

• Python for data analysis (plotting) – students learn how to process and plot data e.g. using the matplotlib library.

• Python for data science – basic introduction to statistical testing and more advanced data visualisation.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Scheduled Lectures: The lectures will provide the theoretical basis for the practical exercises and the background needed to support the assessments.

Attendance Recorded: yes

Workshops: active-learning workshops, which will focus on real world coding tasks, in order to provide students with hands-on experience. Students will undertake formative exercises in class, with feedback from staff and demonstrators during classes on code written and answers to exercises. Students will be encouraged to work in small groups for formative exercises. Learning is consolidated through formative exercises leading up to Summative assessment, of increasing levels of difficulty, where later assignments rely on earlier knowledge and skills.


Attendance Recorded: yes

The student directed learning element of the module will involve directed reading and accessing online resources. This will require adaptability & organisational skills.

The Liverpool Curriculum Framework is at the centre of this module. Research-connected teaching is embedded in all aspects of teaching. This module contributes to a Programme which is specifically designed to support students for future training in Life Sciences and in collaboration with future potential employers– employability. The teaching approach is designed to give students hand-on experience with bioinformatics and advanced computer skills, promoting Digital Fluency through Active Learning. Student Confidence will be promoted though both skills development and through discussion in class and with their project supervisors.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
Notes (applying to all assessments)
The module will be assessed via four assessments. The assessments are designed with The Liverpool Curriculum Framework in mind and are authentic to the research experience and will give students real life experience of coding and analysing real world big data.

Assessment 1 (10%)– Basic coding assignment in which students demonstrate the use of basic text and numerical handling, as well as conditional statements and looping

Assessment 2 (20%)– Basic coding assignment where students demonstrate the writing of functions and use of file input / output.

Assessment 3 (30%)- Basic pipeline assembly. Students learn to connect up multiple functions, to achieve a simple bioinformatics analysis.

Assessment 4 (40%)– Individual large scripting project to produce an analysis with report 1000 words plus code.

Feedback will be provided to all assessments. Pass mark for all assessments is 50%. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission of all assessments. All assessments are anonymous assessment.

Resit strategy: resit opportunity will be given to the assessment and will have the same format and content as the original assessment, but with substantial revision required and will be submitted during the reassessment window and capped at 50% (pass mark).

Learning materials will be available to students via the University Virtual Learning environment. More details on the assessments are on the table below.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessments may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

LIFE733
Notes
I have made a couple of minor changes to the module:

- I removed mention of machine learning (ML) - this is no longer going to be covered in this module. MSc Bioinformatics students will get a more detailed introduction to machine learning in a different module. ML was not appropriate content for students on other programmes, as it was too advanced.

- I have changed the team working assignment to a regular individual assignment.

- In response to student feedback, I have changed the assignment weighting, so they are now 10:20:30:40 - assignments increase in difficulty and complexity to solve. Previously 10:10:30:50. The justification for 4 assignments (instead of 2 say), remains as before - we need students to engage early and continously to learn coding. With a fewer number of students, there is a risk of only passive engagement until it is too late. We are going to trial some automated grading software this year, to reduce the burden on staff.

The rationale for the changes is that the module was designed for classes of size < 20, where all students joining were keen to learn coding.

We now have a class of >50, including cohorts of students on M-level programmes with no particular interest in coding (e.g. from MSc Infection Immunity, for whom it is a mandatory module - presumably as a cost saving exercise).

As such, I have had to simplify the module to handle the increased number of students, and also the wide range of abilities and interests of the cohort. The team working assignment, while highly desirable for students motivated to learn coding, does not work well for teams that contain students who do not engage in the material and work consistently week-by-week.

Overview

Overview
The aim of the module is to develop skills in Python coding for use in Life Sciences research, for example to prepare students for future work either in bioinformatics or for those planning to work in lab-based biosciences with a need to learn more advanced data analysis methods.

The module will be taught using a combination of lectures and workshops. Lecture material will provide some of the background theory, but interactive workshops will provide the main route for students to gain confidence in their coding skills through both formative and summative assessment.

The module will be assessed via four coursework assessments – two short coding assignments for confidence building, one simple bioinformatics pipeline and one data science mini-project.

Learning materials will be available to students via the University Virtual Learning environment.
Educational Aims
-To provide students with sufficient introductory Python coding knowledge to perform basic tasks within the field of biological sciences.
-To enable students to gain practical experience in writing their own Python scripts for basic bioinformatics tasks, such as, manipulating DNA, RNA and protein sequences, file input/output and working with other programs, such as BLAST.
-To provide students with skills and practical experience in the use of Python for data visualisation and basic statistical analysis (i.e. data science)
Marketing Module Synopsis
This module is aimed at postgraduate students in the Biosciences, wishing to learn about methods for use in data-intensive research. The module provides a broad introduction to the use of Python coding for performing basic tasks in the biological sciences. The student will get practical experience in writing their own Python scripts for basic bioinformatics tasks, such as manipulating DNA, RNA and protein sequences, file input/output and working with other programs, such as BLAST. There is also an introduction to data visualisation using Python, and simple techniques used in data science.

Around 10 hours of lectures will be provided on core topics, with a strong emphasis on practical activity in workshops (totalling around 40 hours), allowing students to gain confidence in writing scripts for their own tasks. The module will be assessed by two short coding assignments, one team working coding assignment building a bioinformatics pipeline, and a data science mini-project.
Outline Syllabus
• Introduction to Python – A basic introduction to the Python3 language (basic datatypes – strings, floats, integers), and the PyCharm software we use for writing code. Basic explanation of errors and how to debug errors.

• List, conditionals and loops – Learning how to use basic structures such as list, Boolean statements (if, elif, else) for changing the flow of code, and for loops for repeated actions.

• Dictionaries, lists and looping structures – Covering the use of a Python Dictionaries, a useful structure for storing and managing data, more detail on using multiple structures and components together.

• Functions – Learning how to structure code into functions with arguments and return values.

• Working with files and regular expressions – experience of reading and writing from text files with Python, and using powerful string manipulations.

• External programmes and BioPython – introduction to calling external command line programmes e.g. BLAST and using the BioPython libraries for sequence-based bioinformatics tasks (BLAST, multiple sequence alignment, phylogenetics).

• Python for data analysis (plotting) – students learn how to process and plot data e.g. using the matplotlib library.

• Python for data science – basic introduction to statistical testing and more advanced data visualisation.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Scheduled Lectures: The lectures will provide the theoretical basis for the practical exercises and the background needed to support the assessments.

Attendance Recorded: yes

Workshops: active-learning workshops, which will focus on real world coding tasks, in order to provide students with hands-on experience.
